279.subject: Codespace Hours Limits
279.content: Codespaces has limited hours per month: 120 hours. That is approximately 4 hours per day. You can apply for a GitHub Pro account as a student here: https://education.github.com/discount_requests/applicationLinks to an external site. to get 180 hours per month, which gives you 6 hours per day (more than enough). A bad practice that makes you exhaust the allowed hours is leaving your codespace tab open when not using it, or having an infinite loop that you didn’t stop. You can stop an infinite loop by pressing `Crtl+C in the terminal. In short, if you are done working, please close the codespace.

37.subject: How to change Codespace language to English (if you want to)?
37.content:
1. On a MAC, press on Cmd+Shift+P or on Windows press Crtl+P. 

2. Type in **Configure Display Language**.

3. Pick English as shown below.

![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjlzv60dhucu1fm%2F5b3576904221cbaeda120fb697d35b41f74c59ddbf155ad72bca081320ef99a8%2Fimage.png)

11.subject: How to get rid of "format" in printf statements?
11.content:
The default setting in VS Code on Codespaces shows the parameter name in functions you use. This can be confusing. For example, `format:` shows up as you write down printf statement as shown below.
![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjlzv60dhucu1fm%2Fa3e3e574489f9aeeb3636d7fb2faa8e0af6ec62f3cfbdaa81e881a2eadb7209a%2Fimage.png)

If it is bothering you, you can go to Settings > type in "inlay" and disable inlay hints as shown below (choose off).
![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjlzv60dhucu1fm%2Fc1aeff18497e4ac27ec6fbeb5487aa6d41c22d221cec26ffcad107d95d125986%2Fimage.png)

6.subject: Welcome to APS 105 Piazza Discussion Forum!
6.content: Piazza is a good place for students to ask questions on material discussed in lectures, tutorials and labs. Instructors and TAs will be monitoring Piazza regularly. I strongly encourage students to help each other. Up to 2 bonus marks will be given to the top ten student answerers. Rules for participation: 1- Clearly state your question. Showing just a picture, or writing “It’s not working, and I don’t know why” may not help you get the response required. State what is the problem exactly and it is ideal if you state what you think caused it. 2- Don’t post code. If someone copies code you sent on Piazza, this constitutes as an academic integrity violation for the copier and the provider. If you want to show code, post a private post to the instructors. Wishing you all the best, Salma Emara, Course Coordinator

1120.subject: Comments
1120.content: I just wanted to say that even though the exam was a bit rough, this was still the best course i have taken so far! The teaching team really cared about the students and was always willing to help. Especially with quick Piazza responses and the recorded lectures! Overall this course was extremely enjoyable and fun! 👏
1120.endorsed_answer: I agree. The exam really did catch me off guard because even though I did work on past exams and was able to do labs well and all of that it was quite rough. However I truly did enjoy the course and am still glad I took it (didn't need to choose it as I am an industrial engineering student). The ample support available definitely contributed to the learning experience. For me the textbook was invaluable and I am so grateful for it. I also really loved office hours! I had a kind prof and my TA was also super nice. Thank you to the teaching team! I hope my future courses provide a similar experience and I think other courses (not necessarily programming or even ECE!) would benefit from seeing how this course was structured/done (minus the exam lol).

1119.subject: Comment was encouraged to be posted in main, so here it is
1119.content: After ignoring all the multiple choice questions, the 12 questions (debugging and coding), split across the entire exam time of 2hr 30 minutes, leaves only 12 minutes per question. This is not a reasonable time for the difficulty and length of the questions presented. The problem statements for each question were painfully long to read and confusing in a stress filled environment. Also, there's absolutely no way those questions were to take 10-15 minutes to complete, for slow readers like me it was a challenge to keep track of some questions. I did most past exams, all the textbook questions and previous labs - the difficulty of the questions presented in this particular exam was much much higher compared to that. I would like to suggest that despite the lectures and textbook problems being helpful to learn the content, for today's exam it was not very useful for most of the questions. It feels like all the effort was pretty much useless, the one benefit was that one question was identical from one of the past exams. We weren't suggested to grind LeetCode for an introductory course like APS105, and I hope that the marking is very very lenient or the efforts were put to vain.
1119.instructor_answer:
I'd like to answer this the same way that I answered the comment:

Thank you for sharing your feedback. I don’t think we had 12 “coding questions”, e.g. question 30 explicitly asks you not to write code. Question 29 simply wants to you to look at the code and see that it is returning a pointer to a local variable which is used later on, causing undefined behavior I noticed some students were actually instead running the code. Question 27 simply needs you to remove that extra semicolon. For question 28 you’d have to move the i++ outside of the body of the if statement. In my opinion, these are all questions that can be answered very quickly. Glimpsing at what some students were doing, some were even testing some true/false or MCQ questions with code, which is, in my opinion, a poor time management strategy. Thanks again for sharing your feedback.

1118.subject: advice for next years exam environment
1118.content: please consider providing only one file where you write your code, having so many files makes things confusing and is more prone to error, everyone I know only used one file to write code and ignored the rest, also consider switching back to paper, as it is so easy to spend 10-20 minutes trying to figure out why your compiler or vscode isnt working, and when time pressure is high, it can shift the momentum of your exam and thought process especially when "TA's and the Teaching Team are not responsible for your computer issues" as stated in the annoucement. Not even kidding, the persons computer beside me shut off for 10 minutes of the exam, how is that even fair? imagine someone taking your paper from you on a calc exam for 10 minutes and you just have to sit there and watch everyone else write. T-T hope that person is okay ( 10 minutes can be the difference between you solving the last question or getting a zero on that question )
1118.instructor_answer: Well, you can just use only one file. There is no obligation to use all. We provided you with multiple to help you out organize your environment and save you time. You can also just delete all the folders and write your own if you want. I am not sure if you knew this. Also, it is part of the exam to actually know how to use VS Code. I would be worried if someone doesn't know how to use VS code. For students who had a computer crash were given extra time to cover for the time lost. The IT team is working on ensuring this doesn't happen at all to anyone. I fully understand the stress that comes with technical issues during the exam, but I taught students who did programming exams on paper and on computers. I can confidently say that computer-based exams is pushing students to practice more and efficiently before the exam than paper based exams. I have seen people change their studying habits just because the exam is computer-based. Since the exam is more aligned with what happens in writing your lab assignments than papers, students are more inclined to complete the lab assignments themselves rather than using GenAI tools. We are in a new era. Instead of moving backwards and taking exams on paper, I prefer if we current fix issues with computer-based exams. I am eager to know more about your experiences and will send out a survey soon about it.

1117.subject: Thoughts On Final Exam
1117.content: During the exam, most of my files didn’t compile at all despite being correct and I got the “executor not built yet” error as well. This wasted a lot of time that I could’ve spent thinking about the actual problems. Besides the issues with VS code, the problems were also very long and too complex. Also in comparison to the midterm, which was 1 hour and 50 minutes long for 24 questions, the final was 2 hours and 30 minutes for 38 questions. Considering there were 14 more questions and only forty more minutes, and given difficulty level of the coding questions and issues with VS code, I personally feel that the exam was not a fair assessment. I understand that the second half of the course is much more difficult than the first half, but with such major differences between the two halves of the course, I wish there were more practice questions that reflected this level of difficulty. (but ig they’re prepping us for future leetcode interview questions lmaoo 💀)
1117.instructor_answer: I have read all comments carefully and reflected on what happened. I am writing this after I have submitted final marks. Last year's course average is 74, and this year it is 76. Regarding the compiler, for many of the errors I saw during the exam itself, it was mainly due to running into an infinite loop, probably because of the question on removing spaces from a string. The execution wasn't complete or "Permission denied" or other similar errors were either because there is a compile-time error or because there is a running task from a program having an infinite loop or that didn't exit as it was left hanging waiting for an input. This is why many students had to close VS code and reopen it every time before running a new program. I understand that I haven't seen all errors myself, so there might be other issues. However, I doubt it is a compiler or VS Code issue since these errors didn't happen to everyone. I am not blaming anyone. I am only noting that there might be something you were not aware of how to deal with since the exam environment is new. Regarding the time allocated for the exam, I agree the exam was long compared to the midterm. To be transparent, the midterm was quite short given you were having the aid of a computer, so we were inclined to create a longer final exam. Compared to the midterm, the 14 additional questions were predominantly on the easier side of the exam. To be specific, we had 5 more T/F, 5 more MCQs, 3 more short answer/debugging questions and only 2 more programming questions. I personally felt it was quite fair given that most of the additional questions were relatively easy. However, maybe what we didn't consider much was that additional questions require more reading and understanding before answering, even if they were easy. Also to be fair in my assessment, I have to say that the 2-3 programming questions were way more challenging that previous years final exams, and that was with the intention to challenge those who got full marks in the midterm -- who were many. But also there were questions for everyone (easy, medium, challenging and very challenging). In the end, I took everyone's comments into consideration. The grading was lenient and we did curve the final exam. I can't make anymore comments yet. However, I will make a Quercus announcement about details when I am allowed to do so (after the grades gets approved).

1110.subject: 2022 Q12?
1110.content: Very confused on how to break down what to do based on this question. Not sure what its even asking. Could someone explain/provide tips?
1110.instructor_answer: It's giving you a big linked list where the nodes contain strings as their data instead of ints.  It's asking you to split the list up by first letter, into 26 lists, 1 per possible first letter, then print out the non-empty lists.  There's an extra rule that the ordering should reverse itself for stuff in the same small list, which will trip up people who don't read carefully. The framing device of the question is sorting exams by last name, and you should parse it similarly to how you would parse word problems in math.  Find the important bits, and use the scenario to see what they represent and how they relate to each other.  Unlike math word problems, instead of looking for numbers you're looking for data structure layouts and input/output specifications.

1065.subject: Recursion Output
1065.content: How do we end up with that final output of 33661100? I am having trouble following the process and would appreciate if someone explained/wrote it out 🙏
1065.instructor_answer: The printf("n = %d\n", n); lines are your hint here, writing them down gives you a trace of the internal nodes of the call graph. Lets draw it out: recur(3610) = 33661100 /                  \ x  = recur(361) =336611    y = recur(0) = 00 /                 \ x = recur(36) = 3366       y = recur(1) = 11 /              \ x = recur(3) = 33       y = recur(6) = 66

1064.subject: 2023 question 11
1064.content: Hi, for question 11 in 2023 final exam, I am just wondering if the question requires us to print all the numbers in normal entering order, for example, if you entered "10, 5, 2, 1, 0", and the output will be"10, 5, 2, 1, 0", how should I modify my code to reach this result? Or it is just pointless to think recursion questions like this?
1064.instructor_answer: Recursion would have a hard time with this printing in order, since you're trying to make a stack act like a queue.  Recursive calls form a stack (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stack_(abstract_data_type)), which is a natural data structure for reversing a sequence, but terrible for repeating in order.   You'd either need to create a dynamically allocated data structure (eg a linked list) to use for this, or do some stack smashing (basically hacking, take ECE568 in 4th year to learn it). Technically the best way to achieve this with recursion would be to use a varargs parameter ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Varargs) , which would let you pass the entire sequence down the stack through increasingly larger stack frames.  We don't teach you about varargs in this course though, or even in any of the more advanced courses I know about.  It's a very niche thing.

1033.subject: Node/struct confusion
1033.content: Is 'current->link' equivalent to writing 'current ->next'? And is what I did to answer this question (extra condition in while loop) make it incorrect?
1033.endorsed_answer: We are defining the Node from the ground up with our struct. The node only has components that we create for it. Usually, a Node will be given two fields: value (commonly an int ) and next (a pointer another Node ). In the example you've shown, the Node is defined with the fields: value and link . In this case, link simply acts as a pointer to another Node (i.e. functions as next ) . The key takeaway is that Node s do not inherently have a next ... We create their fields. Usually this will be in the form of some identifier (i.e. the patient id in Lab 9 or the value in your example) and some next value which will allowed Nodes to be connected with each other. After all, there's not much value in a singular Node . Salma: Agree to top! For the extra condition, the question asked you to write code in a specific place. So you will lose marks if you don't follow the instructions. What you did is not wrong but is not needed.

1017.subject: Location of Input Strings
1017.content: Hello, I was wondering if there is any way to know the location in memory of a string inputted into a function? When passing in a ptr to a string, you have no awareness of whether the string was originally allocated as a constant (either using char *ptr or const char *ptr) or on the heap. This changes things as in the scenario where the string is allocated in the heap, you can change the individual characters in the string, while if it is a constant, you'd cause the program to crash. You could allocate everything into the heap but then you run the risk of memory leaks if the original string was already allocated on the heap.

1015.subject: Slow coding speed
1015.content: I found that I was very slow in answering questions. On the one hand, I spent a lot of time reading the questions, and on the other hand, I usually spent a lot of time setting up the test environment when writing programs. For example, the question only requires writing a function, but for the sake of testing, I would write main, user input, and scanf, etc. I am very troubled by this matter. In addition to practicing more questions, may I ask for some tips that could be applied to the exam to help me solve this problem? Are there some ways that I should practice to help me further improve my efficiency?
1015.instructor_answer: We would give you some code to test your function in the exam. I would recommend trying to find patterns in questions. This happens when you solve more. For example, after solving 4-5 string questions, you realize that they require either 1 loop or a nested loop with 1-2 string functions. Next time you see a question, start by asking yourself how many loops do I need and what should they do? Also, can I eliminate a loop by using a string functions I know? Another example, linked lists require having a current pointer to loop over nodes. If the question is about insertion, for example, you need to know the address of the node after which you will insert the node. Ask yourself the 4 top most special cases in linked lists: what happens when the list is empty? When we insert at tail? When we insert at front? What happens if we have one node? In short, asking yourself the right questions help you solve quickly. This will happen automatically in your brain as you start solving more. There is no short cuts.

1010.subject: Textbook question

1010.instructor_answer: You are correct! The line in bold is necessary to ensure it's null-terminated. Recall that strcpy will put \0 if strlen(str) < n char* preamble(char* str, int n) { if (str == NULL) return NULL; char* newString = (char*)malloc((n + 1) * sizeof(char)); strncpy(newString, str, n); newString[n] = '\0'; return newString; }

You would be right if you thought this was bad practice or semantically bad programming. But I think the question was asking about compile errors/adherence to C standard. On my machine compiling with C99 standard, you don't get compile errors if you attempt the options 2 and 3. I only get a warning for option 2.

![image.png](/redirect/s3?bucket=uploads&prefix=paste%2Fjzrmzgzrtro4t8%2F8b4a920dc78930223519b007dcbf4a21ea047094c843c890f004af24556f894a%2Fimage.png)

### For option 2: 
According to the [C 2024 ISO standard](https://www.open-std.org/jtc1/sc22/wg14/www/docs/n3220.pdf), casting a pointer type to any other pointer type is allowed (section 6.5.5). The only constraints are that you cannot convert between "floating type" and "pointer type", and vice versa (section 6.5.5). Only when dereferencing it could we get undefined behavior.
> Among the invalid values for dereferencing a pointer \[...\] are an address inappropriately aligned for the type of object pointed to.” (section 6.5.4.4). 

All that to say that C does allow you to assign double pointers to int addresses, even though it's not good practice and you shouldn't do it in your code.

### For option 3:
This is a little trickier. The ISO says:
> Any pointer type may be converted to an integer type. The result is implementation-defined. If the result cannot be represented in the integer type, the behavior is undefined.

So it is undefined behavior to assign an integer type to a pointer type. I'm not sure what the midterm meant by "invalid" and if it counts in undefined behaviors. Perhaps the instructors can weigh in on this.

999.subject: Advice
999.content: Hello, i am looking for an advice for the final exam. So for me in the midterm i did really bad compared to other people and thats due to the limited time and always i get stressed. Even though for the labs i am doing good where i am using the whole week to understand the requirements and then code. However, for exams i always get stressed and get a really bad mark which happened to me in the midterm. So i am looking for some advice for how to study better and how to overcome the stress. Thank you.
999.instructor_answer: Practice mainly on the past final exams - the questions on this years exam will be similar in content and difficulty. If you’re someone who gets stressed and your performance tanks under pressure, try to simulate that stressful environment and do a few mock exams to get yourself more comfortable with that setting. Eg. go to a library/study room, set a timer and strictly enforce not checking the solution until you’re done the exam. Time management is extremely important on the exam. Just like in the midterm, you will probably be able to solve most problems given enough time. But can you do it fast enough? Most students (from past offerings and present) report that the exams in this course are fair but very long. So you need to learn to spend the right amount of time on each question, and learn to move on when you’ve spent too much time on one question. One trick I find useful is this: when you open the exam, read the last few programming questions first and start thinking about it in the background while you do the easy problems. And of course, practice will help you do everything faster. Definitely spend some time thinking about common idioms of working with linked lists (eg. insertion, deletion, traversal), and memorize them if you have to, so that it becomes second nature to you. Let me know if you have any other questions.

988.subject: Why a focus on recursion?
988.content: Hello, I hope you're doing well I wanted to ask why recursion is a focus in the course? I was going through the textbook exercises but I remember that the process is highly inefficient - memory and timewise. For example, to find the index of a character in a string - recursion will overflow the stack for a high number of calls. I'm curious as to why we're learning about recursion when it's highly discouraged in real code use? Best, Punya
988.instructor_answer: I'm curious where you read that recursion is discouraged?  There are many blog posts arguing back and forth about various programming patterns, but this is definitely not something that is universally true. It is true that the problems we give you tend to be simple 'toy' examples, and for many of these you can easily find a non-recursive solution.  But there are many problems where defining recurrences is key to solving them efficiently, for instance anything under the category of Dynamic Programming ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dynamic_programming) .  Trying to solve a dynamic programming problem without a recurrence blows up in runtime, while it remains tractable with a recurrence, and if the subproblems are sparse then a non-recursive solution will waste a lot of work, assuming that a non-recursive solution is even possible. I will also point out that for the simple problems with just one recursive call that we've given you, the tail recursion optimization ( https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tail-recursion) means that they don't actually take up any more stack space than an iterative approach. Bloggers love to talk down to people, but it's best not to take them too seriously.  Every technique has its uses, even if we aren't giving you the difficult problems that need them.

937.subject: Structs & Linked Lists
937.content: Two questions about structs/linked lists. I know we need the initial declaration to allow us to have node_t in the second node struct, but is this essentially overwriting the first one? Also for the linkedlist struct, the head is of type node_t* , but I have not seen this been assigned a value in any examples, does it still have the value property and it is just unused? Thanks.
937.instructor_answer:
The first  ``typedef struct node node_t``  is a forward declaration so you can use `node_t* inside the struct. It’s not overwritten — the full definition later just completes it.

`head` is a pointer to a node (`node_t*`), so it doesn't directly have a `val` field. But once `head` points to an actual node, you can access the value with `head->val`.

Also, in the future it would be a good idea to include a screenshot of the question you're asking about.  I won't always be able to look it up.

//Pointer temp, points to where the second node and head points to the newly inserted node return true; } //Fx#3: Order patients based on severity bool insertIntoOrderedList(LinkedList *list, int ID, char name [100], int severity){ // The list is empty, so just insert at front. if (list->head == NULL) { return insertAtFront(list, ID, name, severity); current->next = newNode; // Overwrite next with the new node. return true; } //FX#5: Prints entire linked list void printList(LinkedList *list) { //Set pointer current of type patientNode to the very first node patientNode *current = list->head; 891.subject: Algorithm making invalid moves
891.content: Hello, I am trying to test my code for part 2 but my algorithms keeps on making invalid moves and I am not sure why. For example, sometimes it tries to automatically play in the corner aa and sometimes it tries to play on top of its own existing piece. All of my other functions are correct as i am able to pass all of the test cases from lab 7 and lab 8 part 1. I have posted my code for the makemove function below. I would greatly appreciate it if you could take a look at it. Thank you. int makeMove(const char board[][26], int n, char turn, int *row, int *col) { int bestScore = -1; int currentScore1 = 0; int currentScore2 = 0; int currentScore3 = 0; int currentScoreTotal = 0; int bestRow = -1; int bestColumn = -1; int countBeforeFlip = 0; int countAfterFlip = 0; int opponentMovesBeforeFlip = 0; int opponentMovesAfterFlip = 0; char opponent = findOpposite(turn); char copiedBoard[26][26]; char copiedBoard2[26][26]; char copiedBoard3[26][26]; for (int x = 0; x < n; x++) { for (int y = 0; y < n; y++) { copiedBoard3[x][y] = board[x][y]; } } for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { if (board[i][j] == turn) { countBeforeFlip = countBeforeFlip + 1; } } } for (int a = 0; a < n; a++) { for (int b = 0; b < n; b++) { if (moveIsValid(copiedBoard3, n, a, b, opponent) == true) { opponentMovesBeforeFlip = opponentMovesBeforeFlip + 1; } } } for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { if (moveIsValid(board, n, i, j, turn)) { countAfterFlip = 0; opponentMovesAfterFlip = 0; currentScore1 = 0; currentScore2 = 0; currentScore3 = 0; currentScoreTotal = 0; for (int r = 0; r < n; r++) { for (int c = 0; c < n; c++) { copiedBoard[r][c] = board[r][c]; } } for (int r2 = 0; r2 < n; r2++) { for (int c2 = 0; c2 < n; c2++) { copiedBoard2[r2][c2] = board[r2][c2]; } } flipInDirection(copiedBoard, n, i, j, turn); flipInDirection(copiedBoard2, n, i, j, turn); for (int k = 0; k < n; k++) { for (int l = 0; l < n; l++) { if (copiedBoard[k][l] == turn) { countAfterFlip = countAfterFlip + 1; } } } currentScore1 = countAfterFlip - countBeforeFlip - 1; for (int a = 0; a < n; a++) { for (int b = 0; b < n; b++) { if (moveIsValid(copiedBoard2, n, a, b, opponent) == true) { opponentMovesAfterFlip = opponentMovesAfterFlip + 1; } } } currentScore2 = opponentMovesBeforeFlip - opponentMovesAfterFlip; if ((i == 0 && j == 0 && moveIsValid(board, n, 0, 0, turn) == true) || (i == 0 && j == n - 1 && moveIsValid(board, n, 0, n - 1, turn) == true) || (i == n - 1 && j == 0 && moveIsValid(board, n, n - 1, 0, turn) == true) || (i == n - 1 && j == n - 1 && moveIsValid(board, n, n - 1, n - 1, turn) == true)) { currentScore3 = 1; } currentScoreTotal = currentScore1 + 2 * currentScore2 + 7 * currentScore3; if (currentScoreTotal > bestScore) { bestScore = currentScoreTotal; countAfterFlip = 0; currentScoreTotal = 0; opponentMovesAfterFlip = 0; bestRow = i; bestColumn = j; } else { countAfterFlip = 0; currentScoreTotal = 0; opponentMovesAfterFlip = 0; } } } } if (bestRow == -1 || bestColumn == -1 || moveIsValid(board, n, bestRow, bestColumn, turn) == false) { return 0; } else { *row = bestRow; *col = bestColumn; } return 0; }
891.instructor_answer: It's a little challenging to have someone from the teaching team to debug your code a few hours before the deadline. However, I can definitely guide you. What I recommend from your description is to printf out the values of the row and col after they are considered valid and the corresponding score. See if they make sense. Based on what is printed try isolating the cause of the error. Is it the problem of the function that checks if a move is valid? If yes, then have some logging statements that prints out intermediate values of variables and see if they make sense in each step.

875.subject: lab8part 2 Move Time Inquiry

832.subject: Final exam
832.content: How should I study for the final exam to maximize my marks? Are there specific topics that are almost guaranteed to appear on the final? I understand that the material covered before the midterm is still important, but will the final exam focus on specific pre-midterm topics, or primarily on the content introduced afterward?
832.instructor_answer: We will post an announcement about the final exam next week. I would say focus on material discussed after the midterm. We will test you 100% on recursion, strings, linked lists and 2D arrays. All material covered before the midterm are inherently tested in these topics. If we want to make an exam easy, we will have a question or two only on material before the midterm, but most of the marks will been material after the midterm. From experience, students struggle the most with linked lists questions and strings and recursion (in that order).

796.subject: understanding the need or (the lack of a need) to typecast
796.content: if we do double x = 3/2; 3/2 -> 1 and x is stored as 1.000 since it is a double. The computer wasn't confused that 3/2 -> 1 is an int, it simply stored the value as a double 1.000, and no typecasting operation is needed. But when it comes to malloc why do we need still need to  use the typecast operator (int*)? int* myArray = (int*) malloc (5 * sizeof(int));
796.instructor_answer: Because C is strong typed. You can't assign one variable to another variable with different type. If there is no implicit conversion available, C doesn't allow you to do it.

788.subject: Linker error lab8part2
788.content: Hello, After editing the setting.json file, I get this warning after I use the compile button: gcc: warning: /workspace/lab8part2/liblab8part2.a: linker input file unused because linking not done How can I make sure the linking is good?
788.instructor_answer:
This is because we changed compilerArgs and linkerArgs in the settings.json. We should have only changed linkerArgs. `liblab8part2.a` is a precompiled version of the implementations of findSmarter and findSmartest functions. At the time of compiling using VS Code, we don't need to recompile `liblab8part2.a` (it is already compiled). We only need to link it (not compile it). 

In short, if you change from
```
{  
...  
"C\_Cpp\_Runner.compilerArgs": \[  
"${workspaceFolder}/lab8part2/liblab8part2.a"  
\],  
"C\_Cpp\_Runner.linkerArgs": \[  
"${workspaceFolder}/lab8part2/liblab8part2.a"  
\],  
...  
}
```
to
```
{  
...  
"C\_Cpp\_Runner.compilerArgs": \[  
""  
\],  
"C\_Cpp\_Runner.linkerArgs": \[  
"${workspaceFolder}/lab8part2/liblab8part2.a"  
\],  
...  
}
```
you will resolve the warning.

This is a mistake from an old version of the lab that was carried forward.

768.subject: confusion with textbook
768.content: how can we say pNeuron->input = 23.96 pNeuron is a pointer and weve only said it holds the address of a bunch of space from the heap, I dont quite understand how we can say Pneuron-->input = #; without first assigning it to a declared variable of Neuron type
768.instructor_answer: Dynamically allocated variables (from malloc) aren't declared anywhere, but they still exist. Calling malloc(sizeof(Neuron)) creates a variable of Neuron type 1 and returns a pointer to it.  The variable isn't declared anywhere, but it still exists and it has a global scope.  Because it isn't declared, it can only be accessed with its pointer, since there's no variable name for it.  It will exist until something calls free() with a pointer to it, and if you forget to do so you have a memory leak. 1 note that types in C only matter to the compiler, once the program is running everything is memory, as the textbook states.
768.endorsed_answer: Dynamically allocated variables (from malloc) aren't declared anywhere, but they still exist. Calling malloc(sizeof(Neuron)) creates a variable of Neuron type 1 and returns a pointer to it.  The variable isn't declared anywhere, but it still exists and it has a global scope.  Because it isn't declared, it can only be accessed with its pointer, since there's no variable name for it.  It will exist until something calls free() with a pointer to it, and if you forget to do so you have a memory leak. 1 note that types in C only matter to the compiler, once the program is running everything is memory, as the textbook states.

Note that up until this point the test case with 4 dimensions has been correct. running the program __ Enter the board dimension: 6 abcdef a UUUUUU b UUUUUU c UUWBUU d UUBWUU e UUUUUU f UUUUUU Enter board configuration: Bdb Bad Wde Wcb !!! abcdef a UUUBUU b UUUUUU c UWWBUU d UBBWWU e UUUUUU f UUUUUU Available moves for W: bc bd ce da ea eb ec ed Available moves for B: ba bb bc bd ca df ed ef __ my code // part of a program to play reversi #include <stdbool.h> #include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #include <string.h> #include "reversi.h" #define U 'U' // for unoccupied #define B 'B' // occupied by black #define W 'W' // occupied by white void updateBoard(char board[][26]); void printBoard(char board[][26], int n); bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col); void initialBoard(char board[][26], int n); void availableMoves(char board[][26], int n, char colour); int main(void) { char board[26][26]; int n; printf("Enter the board dimension: "); scanf("%d", &n); initialBoard(board, n); printBoard(board, n); updateBoard(board); printBoard(board, n); availableMoves(board, n, W); availableMoves(board, n, B); return 0; } // establish the initial board set up void initialBoard(char board[][26], int n) { // intially make the list all Us for (int row = 0; row < n; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < n; col++) { board[row][col] = U; } } // then put the WB BW pattern at the center int firstIndex = n / 2; int secondIndex = firstIndex - 1; board[firstIndex][firstIndex] = W; board[secondIndex][secondIndex] = W; board[secondIndex][firstIndex] = B; board[firstIndex][secondIndex] = B; } void printBoard(char board[][26], int n) { // printer top row of letter printf(" "); for (int next = 0; next < n; next++) { char letter = 'a' + next; printf("%c", letter); } printf("
"); // then print the actual board for (int row = 0; row < n; row++) { printf("%c ", 'a' + row); // print the alphabet letter at the start of each row for (int col = 0; col < n; col++) { printf("%c", board[row][col]); } printf("
"); } } bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col) { return 0 <= row && row < n && 0 <= col && col < n; } void updateBoard(char board[][26]) { printf("Enter board configuration:
"); char input[4]; // take in one string/input at a time to update board while (strcmp(input, "!!!") != 0) { scanf("%s", input); // colour: input[0], row letter: input[1], column letter: input[2] // to convert row/column letter to number, minus by 'a' ASCII code: 97 board[input[1] - 97][input[2] - 97] = input[0]; } } // checks whether (row, col) is a legal position for a tile of color by // "looking" in the direction specified by deltaRow and deltaCol bool checkLegalInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol) { // define the opponent char opponent; if (colour == B) { opponent = W; } if (colour == W) { opponent = B; } // check whether from the spot (row, col) the pattern of // empty- opponent-opponent...-opponent-colour is followed int rowAfterSpot = row + deltaRow, colAfterSpot = col + deltaCol; // first spot should be U if (board[row][col] != U) { return false; } // next spot should be opponent if (!(positionInBounds(n, rowAfterSpot, colAfterSpot) && board[rowAfterSpot][colAfterSpot] == opponent)) { return false; } // check the next spots, and as soon as you reach a non-opponent spot make // sure it is colour // also, make sure indices are in bounds throughout int currentRow = rowAfterSpot + deltaRow, currentCol = colAfterSpot + deltaCol; for (; positionInBounds(n, currentRow, currentCol) && board[currentRow][currentCol] == opponent; currentRow += deltaRow, currentCol += deltaCol) { } return positionInBounds(n, currentRow, currentCol) && board[currentRow][currentCol] == colour; } void availableMoves(char board[][26], int n, char colour) { printf("Available moves for %c:
", colour); for (int row = 0; row < n; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < n; col++) { if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, -1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, -1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, -1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, 1) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 0) || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 0)) { printf("%c%c
", 'a' + row, 'a' + col); } } } }
749.instructor_answer: Your configuration puts B at (d,b) not (b,d) Enter board configuration: Bdb Bad Wde Wcb !!!

742.subject: Lab 8 files
742.content: I was wondering what the .h files do in our labs. For example, lab8 requires us to include "lab8part1.h". I know that files we typically include contain functions and constants, but I was wondering what this one did. When I opened the file, I only see the function prototype.
742.instructor_answer:
.h files are header files. They are used to list function prototypes. 

When you do #include "lab8part1.h", the first step the compiler will do is replace this line with the contents of the file. This means your file has the function prototypes, but not the implementations. Your job is now to implement those functions.

This is our way of forcing you to use the functions we described. If someone chooses not to do so, it's not a big deal in part 1. For part 2, it is an issue as we will compile your code with our own main function, and our own main function expects that you have implemented the functions in the header file.

Hope this helps!

This is my code #include <stdbool.h> #include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #include "reversi.h" void printBoard(char board[][26], int n); bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col); bool checkLegalInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol); void startBoard(char board[][26], int n); void flipTile(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol); void isValidMove (char board[][26], int n, char colour, int row, int col); void availableMoves (char board[][26], int n, char colour); int main(void) { char board[26][26]; int n; printf("Enter the board dimension: "); scanf("%d", &n); startBoard(board, n); printBoard(board, n); char colour, row, col; printf("Enter board configuration:
"); while (row != '!' || col != '!'|| colour != '!') { scanf(" %c%c%c", &colour, &row, &col); //a is used as index 0 board[row - 'a'][col - 'a'] = colour; } printBoard(board, n); availableMoves(board, n, 'W'); availableMoves(board, n, 'B'); printf("Enter a move:
"); scanf(" %c%c%c", &colour, &row, &col); isValidMove(board, n, colour, row - 'a', col - 'a'); return 0; } // this function will fill the empty board with U W and B // The W AND B pieces will be in the middle void startBoard(char board[][26], int n) { for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { board[i][j] = 'U'; } } int half = n / 2; board[half - 1][half - 1] = 'W'; board[half - 1][half] = 'B'; board[half][half] = 'W'; board[half][half - 1] = 'B'; } void printBoard(char board[][26], int n) { printf("  "); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { printf("%c", 'a' + i); // prints letters from a onwards at the top } printf("
"); // this loop prints the letters going down // and it prints the empty board // we will add letters too fill the empty board for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { printf("%c ", 'a' + i); for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { printf("%c", board[i][j]); } printf("
"); } } bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col) { // setting bounds for where the position can be if (row >= 0 && row < n && col >= 0 && col < n) { return true; } else { return false; } } bool checkLegalInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol) { int i = 1; char oppositeColour; if (colour == 'W') { oppositeColour = 'B'; } else { oppositeColour = 'W'; } // checking if the board is occupied, unoccupied and // if the position is in bounds while ((positionInBounds(n, row + (deltaRow * i), col + (deltaCol * i))) && ((board[row + (deltaRow * i)][col + (deltaCol * i)]) != (colour)) && ((board[row + (deltaRow * i)][col + (deltaCol * i)]) != ('U'))) { i++; if ((positionInBounds(n, row + (deltaRow * i), col + (deltaCol * i))) && (board[row + (deltaRow * i)][col + (deltaCol * i)] == colour)) { return true; } else { if ((positionInBounds(n, row + (deltaRow * i), col + (deltaCol * i))) && (board[row + (deltaRow * i)][col + (deltaCol * i)] == oppositeColour)) { continue; } else { if((positionInBounds(n, row + (deltaRow * i), col + (deltaCol * i)) == false)) { return false; } else { if(board[row + (deltaRow * i)][col + (deltaCol * i)] == colour) { return true; } else { return false; } } } } } return false; } void flipTile(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol) { int count = 1; while (board[row + (deltaRow * count)][col + (deltaCol * count)] != colour) { board[row + (deltaRow * count)][col + (deltaCol * count)] = colour; count++; } } void isValidMove (char board[][26], int n, char colour, int row, int col){ int deltaRow, deltaCol; if ((positionInBounds(n, row, col)) && board [row][col] == 'U'){ for (deltaRow = -1; deltaRow <= 1; deltaRow++){ for (deltaCol = -1; deltaCol <= 1; deltaCol++){ if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, deltaRow, deltaCol) && (deltaCol != 0 || deltaRow != 0)) { board [row][col]= colour; flipTile(board, n, row, col, colour, deltaRow, deltaCol); printf("Valid move.
"); printBoard(board, n); return; } } } printf("Invalid move.
"); printBoard(board, n); return; } else { printf("Invalid move.
"); printBoard(board, n); return; } } void availableMoves (char board[][26], int n, char colour){ int row, col; int deltaRow, deltaCol; bool found = false; printf("Available moves for %c:
", colour); for (row = 0; row <= n-1; row++) { for (col = 0; col <= n-1; col++) { if (board[row][col] == 'U') { for (deltaRow = -1; deltaRow <= 1; deltaRow++) { if (found == true) { found = false; break; } for (deltaCol = -1; deltaCol <= 1; deltaCol++) { if (deltaRow == 0 && deltaCol == 0) { } else { if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, deltaRow, deltaCol)) { printf("%c%c
", row + 'a', col + 'a'); found = true; } } } } } } } }
722.instructor_answer: Seems like you are not flipping titles for some directions. It is quite challenging to debug code with this length, but I looked at the condition for under which you flip titles. It does not look right for deltaCol and deltaRow conditions. I urge you to read it out loud to yourself. ``` if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, deltaRow, deltaCol) && (deltaCol != 0 || deltaRow != 0)) ``` You will need to fix this anyways for lab 8. 714.subject: Lab 7 code issue
714.content:
Hello, I am having two issues, which I would greatly appreciate if I could get some help for. For the first and second test cases, when I test them in my terminal one at a time, the outputs are exactly what they should be. However, when I write test, it shows that they are completely wrong. For example it shows that for the first test case my code says the move is invalid even though when I tested it everything is fine. It even shows that I do not display the available moves even though I do. This is the image from my test case in the terminal: My second issue is that when I flip in a direction, only the pieces in that direction get flipped, and the ones southwest or southeast, etc. do not get flipped. For example for test case 4 final output: my code does makes all of the flips in row c, but it does not make ED black and DC black. I would greatly appreciate some help with these two issue. This is my code: #include <stdbool.h> #include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #include <string.h> //#include "reversi.h" #define UNOCCUPIED 'U' #define BLACK 'B' #define WHITE 'W' void printBoard(char board[][26], int n); void initializeBoard(char board[][26], int n); void boardConfiguration(char board[][26]); void availableMoves(char board[][26], int n, char colour); bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col); bool moveIsValid(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour); void flipInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour); bool checkLegalInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol); int main(void) { char board[26][26]; int n; printf("Enter the board dimension: "); scanf("%d", &n); initializeBoard(board, n); printBoard(board, n); boardConfiguration(board); printBoard(board, n); availableMoves(board, n, WHITE); availableMoves(board, n, BLACK); char userInput2[4]; printf("Enter a move:
"); scanf("%s", userInput2); char colourToMove = userInput2[0]; int rowToMove = userInput2[1] - 'a'; int colToMove = userInput2[2] - 'a'; if (moveIsValid(board, n, rowToMove, colToMove, colourToMove) == true){ printf("Valid move.
"); flipInDirection(board, n, rowToMove, colToMove, colourToMove); printBoard(board, n); } else { printf("Invalid move.
"); printBoard(board, n); } return 0; } void initializeBoard(char board[][26], int n) { for (int row = 0; row < n; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < n; col++) { board[row][col] = UNOCCUPIED; } } board[n / 2 - 1][n / 2 - 1] = WHITE; board[n / 2][n / 2 - 1] = BLACK; board[n / 2][n / 2] = WHITE; board[n / 2 - 1][n / 2] = BLACK; } void printBoard(char board[][26], int n) { printf("  "); for (int col = 0; col < n; col++) { printf("%c", 'a' + col); } printf("
"); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { printf("%c ", 'a' + i); for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { printf("%c", board[i][j]); } printf("
"); } } void boardConfiguration(char board[][26]) { char userInput[4]; printf("Enter board configuration:
"); scanf("%s", userInput); while (strcmp(userInput, "!!!") != 0) { char letter = userInput[0]; int row = userInput[1] - 'a'; int col = userInput[2] - 'a'; if (letter == BLACK) { board[row][col] = BLACK; } else { board[row][col] = WHITE; } scanf("%s", userInput); } } bool positionInBounds(int n, int row, int col) { bool inBounds = false; if (row < n && col < n && row >= 0 && col >= 0) { inBounds = true; } return inBounds; } bool checkLegalInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour, int deltaRow, int deltaCol) { int checkRow1 = row + deltaRow; int checkColumn1 = col + deltaCol; int checkRow2 = row + 2 * deltaRow; int checkColumn2 = col + 2 * deltaCol; if (positionInBounds(n, checkRow1, checkColumn1) == false) { return false; } if (positionInBounds(n, checkRow2, checkColumn2) == false) { return false; } if (colour == BLACK) { if (board[checkRow1][checkColumn1] != WHITE) { return false; } } else { if (board[checkRow1][checkColumn1] != BLACK) { return false; } } while (positionInBounds(n, checkRow1, checkColumn1) == true && board[checkRow1][checkColumn1] != colour) { if (board[checkRow1][checkColumn1] == UNOCCUPIED) { return false; } else if (board[checkRow1][checkColumn1] == colour) { return true; } checkRow1 = checkRow1 + deltaRow; checkColumn1 = checkColumn1 + deltaCol; } } bool moveIsValid(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour) { bool valid = false; if (board[row][col] == BLACK || board[row][col] == WHITE) { return false; } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 0) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, 1) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 1) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, -1) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, -1) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, -1) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 0) == true || checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 1) == true) { valid = true; } return valid; } void availableMoves(char board[][26], int n, char colour) { printf("Available moves for %c:
", colour); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) { if (moveIsValid(board, n, i, j, colour) == true) { printf("%c%c", 97 + i, 97 + j); printf("
"); } } } } void flipInDirection(char board[][26], int n, int row, int col, char colour){ board[row][col] = colour; // places the piece in the given row and col if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 0) == true){ while (board[row + 1][col] != colour){ board[row +1][col] = colour; row = row + 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, 1) == true){ while (board[row][col + 1] != colour){ board[row][col + 1] = colour; col = col + 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, 1) == true){ while (board[row + 1][col + 1] != colour){ board[row + 1][col + 1] = colour; row = row + 1; col = col + 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 1, -1) == true){ while (board[row + 1][col - 1] != colour){ board[row + 1][col - 1] = colour; row = row + 1; col = col - 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, 0, -1) == true){ while (board[row][col - 1] != colour){ board[row][col - 1] = colour; col = col - 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, -1) == true){ while (board[row - 1][col - 1] != colour){ board[row - 1][col - 1] = colour; row = row - 1; col = col - 1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 0) == true){ while (board[row - 1][col] != colour){ board[row - 1][col] = colour; row = row -1; } } if (checkLegalInDirection(board, n, row, col, colour, -1, 1) == true){ while (board[row - 1][col + 1] != colour){ board[row - 1][col + 1] = colour; row = row - 1; col = col + 1; } } }

670.subject: Textbook question
670.content: I am confused by this part, isn't the columns already known as we already define it at the first line? if it is the column is changing each time then it is unknown, isn't row also changing?
670.instructor_answer: This is related to your prior question @647.  In this case, the second dimension of the array is not being provided in the declaration of the array (because it's being allocated with malloc), so you can't use [][] to access a row and column.  You need to translate the 2D row and column indices to a 1D (row*ncols + col) index. The number of rows is indeed also "unknown" (you can see it defined here because it's a toy example, but realistically if you're using dynamic allocation it's because you didn't know in advance), but for 1D arrays that doesn't stop you from using it for indexing because the size of the element type is all you need for the pointer math there.
670.endorsed_answer: This is related to your prior question @647.  In this case, the second dimension of the array is not being provided in the declaration of the array (because it's being allocated with malloc), so you can't use [][] to access a row and column.  You need to translate the 2D row and column indices to a 1D (row*ncols + col) index. The number of rows is indeed also "unknown" (you can see it defined here because it's a toy example, but realistically if you're using dynamic allocation it's because you didn't know in advance), but for 1D arrays that doesn't stop you from using it for indexing because the size of the element type is all you need for the pointer math there.

666.subject: understanding the need for memory space outside of just arrays
666.content: When it comes to arrays, we have the option to dynamically array memory in order to avoid running out of memory space. But what about all the other data types? Isn't it possible for those to make us run out of space and make the program crash? So what "preventative methods" do we have for those other data types?
666.instructor_answer:
The reason for dynamic memory allocation is flexibility (to allocate and deallocate whenever you want in your program). One benefit out of this is to use memory efficiently. 

There is nothing that prevents you from dynamically allocating space for a single variable. For example, we can dynamically allocate a single double using

`double* ptrToDouble = malloc(sizeof(double) * 1);`

But here you have the pointer stored on the stack with size 8 bytes and the double itself on the heap with another 8 bytes. This is versus having only a double variable on the stack: `double y;` In terms of space, dynamically allocating one variable is not worth it.

>Isn't it possible for those to make us run out of space and make the program crash? So what "preventative methods" do we have for those other data types?

If you as a programmer know that your program is memory heavy, you can in fact compile your program and set a requirement for the stack/heap size. If you don't want to do so, then you have to be critical of the amount of memory you use by being efficient. 

We don't get into efficient coding in APS105. We slightly touch on it in ECE 244 and delve deeper in ECE 345. The main objective as you prototype and draft code is to make it work (100% functional), then you start thinking about memory/space and time efficiency.

void insertPiece(char gameBoard[][COLS], int columnEntered, char turn); void switchTurn(char *turn); bool checkOneDirection(char gameBoard[][COLS], int row, int col, int rowDir, int colDir); bool checkWinner(char gameBoard[][COLS]); bool fullBoard(char gameBoard[][COLS]); int main() { char gameBoard[][COLS] = { {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}, {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}, {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}, {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}, {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}, {'-', '-', '-', '-', '-', '-'}}; char turn = 'R'; while (!(checkWinner(gameBoard)) || !(fullBoard(gameBoard))) { printBoard(gameBoard); int columnEntered = getInput(gameBoard, turn); insertPiece(gameBoard, columnEntered, turn); switchTurn(&turn); } } void printBoard(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++) { printf("%c", gameBoard[row][col]); } printf("\n"); } } int getInput(char gameBoard[][COLS], char turn) { int inputcol; bool fullcol = true; do { if (turn == 'R') { printf("Red, please enter a valid column number (0-5): "); } if (turn == 'Y') { printf("Yellow, please enter a valid column number (0-5): "); } scanf("%d", &inputcol); if (inputcol >= 0 && inputcol <= 5) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++) { if (gameBoard[row][inputcol] == '-') { fullcol = false; } } } } while (inputcol < 0 || inputcol > 5 || fullcol); return inputcol; } void insertPiece(char gameBoard[][COLS], int columnEntered, char turn) { int row = 5; while (gameBoard[row][columnEntered] != '-' && row >= 0) { row -= 1; } gameBoard[row][columnEntered] = turn; } void switchTurn(char *turn) { if (*turn == 'Y') { *turn = 'R'; } else if (*turn == 'R') { *turn = 'Y'; } } bool checkOneDirection(char gameBoard[][COLS], int row, int col, int rowDir, int colDir) { char spot = gameBoard[row][col]; if (spot == '-') { return false; } int check = 1; for (int currentrow = row + rowDir, currentcol = col + colDir; 0 <= row && row < ROWS && 0 <= col && col < COLS && check <= 3; currentrow += rowDir, currentcol += colDir, check++) { if (gameBoard[currentrow][currentcol] != spot) { return false; } } return check == 4; } bool checkWinner(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++) { if (checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 0, 1) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 0, -1) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, 0) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, -1, 0) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, -1) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, -1, 1) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, 1) || checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, -1, -1)) { return true; } } } return false; } bool fullBoard(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; row++) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; col++) { if (gameBoard[row][col] == '-') { return false; } } } return true; 647.subject: Textbook question
647.content: I am confused by this part in the textbook, myArray represent the first row, while *myArray represent the first element in the first row, but they have the same address which is the address of the first element of the row, I am wondering if this is correct? and why are the two addresses same?
647.instructor_answer: The reason is that 2D arrays aren't actually arrays of arrays.  A nxm 2D array is actually a 1D array with nxm elements.  myArray[0][0] = myArray[0], and myArray[1][0] = myArray[n], myArray[2][3]  = myArray[2*n+3], etc. If you want to get an array of arrays, you could make an int** manually, in which case none of this would apply, but a declaration with 2 sets of square brackets will do it like this and return an int*.

599.subject: Out-of-memory error
599.content:
can anyone go over my code, I don't know why I get this out-of-memory error, I've went over posts about this error and still don't know how to fix this. here is my code: #include <stdbool.h> #include <stdio.h> #define ROWS 6 #define COLS 6 #define EMPTY '-' #define RED 'R' #define YELLOW 'Y' void initializeBoard(char gameBoard[ROWS][COLS]); void printBoard(char gameBoard[][COLS]); bool colFull(int col, char gameBoard[][COLS]); bool boardFull(char gameBoard[][COLS]); int getInput(char gameBoard[][COLS], char turn); void insertPiece(char gameBoard[][COLS], int columnEntered, char turn); void switchTurn(char* turn); bool checkOneDirection(char gameBoard[][COLS], int row, int col, int rowDir, int colDir); bool checkWinner(char gameBoard[][COLS]); int main(void) { char gameBoard[ROWS][COLS]; char turn = RED; bool winner = false; initializeBoard(gameBoard); while (!winner && !boardFull(gameBoard)) { printBoard(gameBoard); insertPiece(gameBoard, getInput(gameBoard, turn), turn); winner = checkWinner(gameBoard); switchTurn(&turn); } if (boardFull(gameBoard) && !winner) { printf("It's a tie
"); } else if (winner) { if (turn == RED) { printf("Yellow wins!
"); } else { printf("Red wins!
"); } } printf("Final board: 
"); printBoard(gameBoard); return 0; } void initializeBoard(char gameBoard[ROWS][COLS]) { for (int row = ROWS - 1; row >= 0; --row) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; ++col) { gameBoard[row][col] = EMPTY; } } } void printBoard(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int row = ROWS - 1; row >= 0; --row) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; ++col) { printf("%c", gameBoard[row][col]); } printf("
"); } } bool colFull(int col, char gameBoard[][COLS]) { if (gameBoard[ROWS - 1][col] != EMPTY) { return true; } return false; } bool boardFull(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int i = 0; i < COLS; ++i) { if (!colFull(i, gameBoard)) { return false; } } return true; } int getInput(char gameBoard[][COLS], char turn) { int col_num; do { if (turn == RED) { printf("Red, please enter a valid column number (0-5): "); } else if (turn == YELLOW) { printf("Yellow, please enter a valid column number (0-5): "); } scanf("%d", &col_num); } while (col_num < 0 || col_num > 5 || colFull(col_num, gameBoard)); return col_num; } void insertPiece(char gameBoard[][COLS], int columnEntered, char turn) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; ++row) { if (gameBoard[row][columnEntered] == EMPTY) { gameBoard[row][columnEntered] = turn; break; } } } void switchTurn(char* turn) { if (*turn == RED) { *turn = YELLOW; } else { *turn = RED; } } bool checkOneDirection(char gameBoard[][COLS], int row, int col, int rowDir, int colDir) { char currentIndex = gameBoard[row][col]; int endRow = row + rowDir * 3; int endCol = col + colDir * 3; int checkingRow; int checkingColumn; if (currentIndex == EMPTY) { return false; } else if (endRow < 0 || endRow >= ROWS || endCol < 0 || endCol >= COLS) { return false; } else { for (int i = 0; i < 4; ++i) { checkingRow = row + rowDir * i; checkingColumn = col + colDir * i; if (checkingRow < 0 || checkingRow > ROWS - 1 || checkingColumn < 0 || checkingColumn > COLS - 1) { return false; }  // check the index is within bounds else if (gameBoard[checkingRow][checkingColumn] != currentIndex) { return false; } } } return true; } bool checkWinner(char gameBoard[][COLS]) { for (int row = 0; row < ROWS; ++row) { for (int col = 0; col < COLS; ++col) { if (checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, 0)) { return true; }  // check rowdirection if (checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 0, 1)) { return true; }  // check columndirection if (checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, 1)) { return true; }  // check diagonals if (checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, -1, -1)) { return true; } } } return false; }
599.instructor_answer: `checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, 1, 1)` and `checkOneDirection(gameBoard, row, col, -1, -1)` check the same direction. The other diagonal is from top left to bottom right.

585.instructor_answer: Lab 6 doesn't need dynamic memory allocation. As the announcement on Friday mentioned, you need knowledge of 2D arrays, functions and loops. All, labs 7 to 9 will be challenging as they are worth more marks, so make sure to start those early.

This indeed made the exam easier. 3- As instructors, we might have under estimated your abilities. 4- As instructors, we might have had easier questions than prior years. 5- This might be an exceptional cohort of students. 6- Resources like Alan, Snefru textbook and lecture recordings might have made everyone's learning experience better. 7- The idea of computer-based exams scared many students and forced them to do the labs themselves as they know the exam format will be similar. Also, this might have made students practice programming questions more using VS Code making them more prepared for the exam. What do you think? I am genuinely interested to hear your view points :)

570.subject: Understanding dynamic memory
570.content: lets say we have an array in function 2, function 2 ends and we do free(array) to avoid memory leak, what happens to the memory or like the array that is stored in heap, currently I just see it as, once you free(array), the memory in the heap is put in a available state for reuse later on outside of function2, is that all there is? does the memory in the heap ever move after you do free(array)
570.instructor_answer: Actually that's up to the standard library. Once you free the memory, the standard library will decide what to do with that memory space. In general, no, the memory after free doesn't move. The standard library has its own way to mark that memory space as empty and allow future malloc to use that memory.
570.endorsed_answer: Actually that's up to the standard library. Once you free the memory, the standard library will decide what to do with that memory space. In general, no, the memory after free doesn't move. The standard library has its own way to mark that memory space as empty and allow future malloc to use that memory.

565.subject: Is it possible to still make a comeback
565.content: I really do not think I performed the best of my abilities on this midterm, and it’s mainly because this is my first time programming ever. I know there was warnings about time management but unfortunately I just could not. What can I do differently for the final? I think it will be way more intense too but I’m already feeling overwhelmed compared to my peers who have programmed before and it comes naturally to them. I do the labs myself and that alone takes me multiple hours. I guess more practice but learning the content takes time as well
565.instructor_answer: I applaud you for being self-aware and for asking for advice and help! That’s an excellent first step! This feels like it should be a conversation. I recommend you speak with your instructor or your TA. I want to know more about your study habits, and in general, how did you prepare to better guide you. I think programming is not easy for beginners. I myself almost failed a programming midterm because my study habits didn’t align well with programming. I did have a comeback in my second midterm as an undergraduate where I got the highest mark. What did I do differently? I spoke with my instructor, and she told me that practice makes perfect. Lab assignments are not enough, and you have to look at many practice problems to get it. I was discouraged initially when I look at a problem and I struggle doing it. I realized struggling and making mistakes is part of the learning process. You won’t get better by looking at someone’s code or by reading notes. I used to play basketball, so I will use this analogy. I didn’t get better at basketball by watching the NBA. I got better by playing more in the field. It took time and effort, but results are guaranteed. Feel free to come and see me! I am willing to give more advice and maybe follow up with you every week if you want :)
565.endorsed_answer: As someone who struggled to learn coding before, I found it very difficult starting out, but I learned certain techniques and ways of practicing that really helped. Here is some advice I have overall and for the course: For learning: I found it really helpful to understand not only what code does, but why it is used and its purpose. For example, why do we use a do while loop vs. a while loop. This will help in problem solving as you can recognize which "tools" you may use in your program. The course textbook is really useful to read and well-written. There are quizzes and exercises in each chapter that were good practice. When looking at coding examples, break down their solution and ask yourself why each line is important. Maybe print it out and write comments as well as trace it to understand what is happening. For labs/problem solving: If you find you are working on a problem for too long, step back and take a break to think it over. Instead, maybe think about the problem on your walk to class or when you're not at the computer screen. This may sound crazy, but a lot of the times I think of solutions while I'm trying to fall asleep, so I keep a notepad nearby to write it down and try it out later. Try approaching the problem without thinking of code first and write down the logical steps you would do as comments in your c program. Then for each comment you write think of a way to replace it with code and tackle it in steps by thinking what "tool" can you use. It is easy to fall into the trap of trying to code first and feeling frustrated because there is no direction. For examinations: While learning and labs should prepare you well for the exams, I do have some tips that may help Obviously, doing past examinations are very important, but try to find patterns of certain types of questions and relate them to concepts. This way you can profile these questions and have an idea of where to start. The past midterms showed themes of: Conditional statements: compare values and print something out based on it (usually with if, else if, and else statements) Modulus operator and integer division: use to get digits of an integer number and then do something with it, finding divisors Nested loops: star printing questions Arrays: iterate through array and read values of array to do something like finding the largest number Time management: Its pressuring to see a clock counting down and you're not thinking fast enough. When doing midterm problems, time yourself but don't look at the clock until you finish. I found that this gave me an internal clock to know when I should move on to the next question and comeback without feeling pressured. It also made me trust myself more with time management as sometimes when looking at the clock once you're done, you spent less time than expected. Closer to the exam date you can look at the clock while doing practice problems to simulate the actual exam. You can also scroll through the exam and look at the problem solving questions so while you're doing the multiple choice, you start thinking about it before you face it. You can also allocate how much time you should use on each question. (for multiple choice maybe max 20 min and the last question, usually the hardest will be 20 min, this is up to how well you know your abilities and certain questions you are good at) Learning how to code is difficult. I remember spending countless hours trying to do assignments and memorizing solutions to problems in hopes of succeeding. Although, from my experience practice for me is less about solving or knowing how to do problems, but more about learning "tools" and patterns that I know when to apply. Before I would try to do every single question for practice (which is good, but takes a lot of time); however, after a while you start to see patterns where solutions click easily. In simple words, you learn what some code does, but you need to learn when you use it. I hope that my advice helps, reading your post took me back to when I first started coding and felt like it was impossible to improve. Don't give up and continue to work hard!

551.subject: Function with Array
551.content: I cannot understand whatsoever how this ends up outputting the values 1 7 21 35 21 7 1, especially since the values start at 0. I am debugging it and didn't really see those values appear, and I dont see how the values get stored into the pascal array and returned into main(). I went through the textbook explanations as well but couldn't wrap my head around it. Could someone explain it?
551.instructor_answer: You're probably familiar with Pascal's Triangle: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pascal%27s_triangle This code is calculating the 7th row by building the triangle one row at a time.  The thing that makes it tricky to understand is that instead of making a 2d array, it's just repeatedly reusing the same 1d array for each row. The outer loop is going down one row at a time, the inner loop is going across 1 entry at a time, and it's overwriting the previous row with the current one until it finishes row 7.

522.subject: arr vs *arr
522.content: Hi, If I have code like the following: int arr[2] = {10, 20}; *p = arr; *q = *arr; Are *p and *q both 10, and do they have the same address?
522.instructor_answer: *p and *q are both 10, but they do not have the same address (p != q). In this case, p will point to the start of the array, but q points somewhere else. This means that if you modify arr[0] you will also modify *p (aliasing), but you will not modify *q . Similarly you can modify the contents of arr[0] by modifying *p, but cannot do the same with q. Also, unless you have already pointed q to something before running this code, it will segfault. Salma: If p and q were declared as int* p, *q; , then *p = arr is not a valid statement as *p is an int and arr is an address to an integer.  Same issue with *q = *arr; The question has mistakes. Please tell us what was the underlying concept you intended to ask about, and we will fix the question together.

504.subject: 2022 midterm question 9
504.content: Hi, I was confused about the use of the boolean variable here, can someone explain what bool same = true; exactly means? Thanks!
504.instructor_answer: boolean have two possible values, either true or false.  The meanings are exactly what they say they are, and you can use them in if statements (note that you need a header for these, since they aren't part of the C language specification). In this case, the for loops have conditions that have two clauses joined with AND, so both must be true before each loop iteration for the loop to continue.  One of them is a boolean variable, which just evaluates to its value, the other is a comparison.

503.subject: Marks on coding style. How does it work during midterm?
503.content: Hi, remembering the lectures and in-person lab grading, I am wondering: Will the coding style be part of a rubric? If yes, are we advised to write comments in our code to possibly get partial marks/marks for coding style? Also, I am not familiar how partial marks work for programming tests. So, could you please explain how one can possibly get partial marks, for example, in a question like "write a complete C program", if not able to finish it entirely? Thank you!
503.instructor_answer:
No marks on coding style, but try not to have a terrible style to help your TA understand your code. If your TA can easily understand your code, there is a higher chance you'll get the marks you deserve. 

Regarding partial marks, think of calculus/dynamics exams. If there are multiple steps to reach the final answer, you are getting partial marks on each step you take. It doesn't matter what approach you are taking as long as the logic in the step is right. 

In programming, the same happens. For example, you are asked to write a program that asks the user to take input integers from the user till they enter a 0 and print their sum. Say that question is worth 9 marks. 3 marks will be on if you are taking input from the user, 3 marks on if your program stops as the user enters 0, 3 marks on calculating and printing correctly. These marks are not binary too. You can get partial credit per each step. For example, if you didn't take input from the user fully correctly, you might get 1/3 or 2/3 depending on how many mistakes you made in the step.

But I'm getting this error, because I don't think int is supposed to be a number starting with 0. Is there any other way to store the barcode?
502.instructor_answer:
We didn't discuss different numbering systems, but numbers starting in 0 are considered octal. Octal numbering system has numbers from 0-7 only. 

Just remove the leading 0. If you ever want to know the $$i$$th digit, you divide by $$10^i$$. If it is 0, then the digit wasn't there which is equivalent to having a leading 0.

491.content: Hey, I've noticed some differences in midterm formats compared to previous years. In previous years, the 13 questions had 10 or more T/F questions bundled into one question, and multiple MCQs bundled into one. On Quercus, we can't have that. Each T/F or MCQ is counted as one question.

484.subject: 2024 Midterm question 9
484.content: Is ++i same as i++ in this case?
484.instructor_answer: In this case, yes. In general, the difference between i++ and ++i is what the expression returns. x = i++ sets x equal to i, then increments i, so x is what i used to be. x = ++i increments i, then sets x equal to i, so x is the new value of i. If you don't use the returned value from the increment, then they're the same.

483.instructor_answer: The line if (i=6) is an assignment statement that makes i equal to 6, not a comparison. Thus the value of i has been changed to 6. If you want a comparison statement it will be: if(i==6) with double equals instead of just one.

482.subject: Errors
482.content: What are all the different types of errors we should be aware of ? aka know what they are and how they work
482.instructor_answer:
There are syntax errors, which happens when you don’t follow rules of C programming language like missing a semicolon. Having syntax errors doesn’t make your program compile as the compiler can’t compile code that doesn’t follow rules.

There are runtime errors, which happens when the program compiles fine, but something happens at execution that makes it crash. We didn’t yet dig into it in depth, but an example is when you are looping through elements in an array and by mistake you index through elements outside the bounds of the array and the program crashes with an error like “Segmentation fault.”

Logical errors happen when you program compiles and run fine and exits successfully, but the output is not expected as you did for example a wrong calculation or you missed a step.

481.subject: Compile-time errors vs warnings - 2020 Midterm Q3
481.content: What's the difference between compile-time errors vs compile-time warnings? I know that warnings will be identified by the compiler but the code will still run whereas errors will cause the program to not build. How would I identify whether a line of code will produce an error or a warning if I know that there is something wrong with the code (like the first and third option below)?
481.instructor_answer: In general, an error means that what you typed in doesn't make sense and the compiler isn't sure what you meant, while a warning means that the compiler knows what you meant but you have bad enough coding style that the compiler devs are telling you to do better. So x=*useCount is an error because you can't dereference an integer.  It's the wrong size to treat as a pointer and might be negative, so the compiler can't convert it. int * q = &y is a warning because &y is an int**, but you're assigning it to an int * .  All pointers are convertible, so the compiler can make this happen, but you should be keeping better track of your types, so you get a warning.
