476.subject: Penalized for "best solution"?
476.content: I was wondering if we lose marks for not having the 'ideal' solution on the midterm. for example, for Q13 from 2014's midterm, the solution is: #include <stdio.h> void sumAndProductOfMultiples(int multiple1, int multiple2, int max, int* sumPtr, int* productPtr); int main(void) { int multi1 = 3, multi2 = 5, max = 10; int sum, product; // add your call to sumAndProductOfMultiples here: sumAndProductOfMultiples(multi1, multi2, max, &sum, &product); printf("m1 = %d, m2 = %d, max = %d, sum = %d, product = %d\n", multi1, multi2, max, sum, product); return 0; } void sumAndProductOfMultiples(int multiple1, int multiple2, int max, int* sumPtr, int* productPtr) { *sumPtr = 0, *productPtr = 1; int i; for (i = 1; i < max; i++) { if (i % multiple1 == 0 || i % multiple2 == 0) { *sumPtr += i; *productPtr *= i; } } } But i did this, which accomplishes the same thing but with an extra loop. #include <stdio.h> void sumAndProductOfMultiples(int multiple1, int multiple2, int max, int* sumPtr, int* productPtr); int main(void) { int multi1 = 3, multi2 = 5, max = 10; int sum, product; // add your call to sumAndProductOfMultiples here: sumAndProductOfMultiples(multi1, multi2, max, &sum, &product); printf("m1 = %d, m2 = %d, max = %d, sum = %d, product = %d\n", multi1, multi2, max, sum, product); return 0; } void sumAndProductOfMultiples(int multiple1, int multiple2, int max, int* sumPtr, int* productPtr) { for (int i = 1; i * multiple1 < max; ++i) { if (i == 1) { *sumPtr = multiple1; *productPtr = multiple1; } else { *sumPtr += i * multiple1; *productPtr *= i * multiple1; } } for (int i = 1; i * multiple2 < max; ++i) { *sumPtr += i * multiple2; *productPtr *= i * multiple2; } } Would i lose marks for this?
476.instructor_answer: You do not lose marks if it is not identical to the model answer, as long as you get the corrct logic.
476.endorsed_answer: You do not lose marks if it is not identical to the model answer, as long as you get the corrct logic.

466.subject: Questions where you are asked to find errors in the code and rewrite it
466.content: Hello, I want to ask about specific type of questions where it is asked to find errors in somebody's code and rewrite it correctly. What is the range of correct answers for this type of questions? Let me explain, sometimes I find that deciphering someone else's code takes more time than simply writing a functional version from scratch (due to different coding styles, weird initialization names and so on). So, lets say the question asks to find errors in a code which uses do-while loop. Instead of unraveling a "weird" written do-while loop, I go ahead and write a functional program using for-loop. Will it still be considered a correct answer to this question? Or is it necessary to preserve the exact structure of the original code while fixing the specific errors? Thank you so much for your answer in advance.
466.instructor_answer: I think you should show that you could find the error, and rewriting from scratch wouldn't do that. If you need to rewrite code every time you read it, you will have a very hard time collaborating with other programmers, and just about any significant project has more than 1 developer.
466.endorsed_answer: I think you should show that you could find the error, and rewriting from scratch wouldn't do that. If you need to rewrite code every time you read it, you will have a very hard time collaborating with other programmers, and just about any significant project has more than 1 developer.

465.subject: using the Snefru chat box
465.content: When using the Snefru chatbox, it does seem very useful,  but how can we be sure that it is correct? For example in my conversation pasted below, the textbook doesn't explicitly explain that, so I can't double check. Below is a snapshot from Snefru chatbox of my conversation. _________________________ when we add 1 to an address is it really just adding 1 or is it adding 1*sizeof(data type)? When you add 1 to a pointer address in C, it actually adds 1 * sizeof(data_type} . This means the pointer arithmetic takes into account the size of the data type that the pointer is pointing to. For example, if you have an int pointer and you add 1 to it, it will move the pointer by the size of an integer (typically 4 bytes on many systems). Read more in: Chapter 08 - Dynamic-memory-allocation: Exercises what about minusing two pointers? what does this reveal about pointer arithmetic ? When you subtract two pointers in C, the result is the number of elements of the data type between the two pointers, not the number of bytes. This means that the subtraction operation returns the difference in terms of the number of elements pointed to, taking into account the size of the data type. For example, if you have two int pointers, ptr1 and ptr2 , and you perform the operation ptr1 - ptr2 , the result will be an integer representing how many int elements are between the two pointers. The arithmetic is performed in terms of the base type size, so the result will be unit-less—in terms of how many elements are between them. followupNew Question
465.instructor_answer: If you want to double-check what the LLM said, the best thing to do is either try out what it said or google it.  In your case, googling your second question results found me this post: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39984816/when-subtracting-two-pointers-in-c TL;DR  The bots answer was technically wrong (subtracting pointers is undefined behaviour unless they both point to elements of a single array allocation), but in practice will be correct because compiler devs don't deliberately punish coders for bad practices.

458.subject: Seed and rand
458.content: Hello, can someone help me understand rand and the role of a seed better? I understand that rand outputs a random number between 0 and some RAND_MAX(which I am not entirely sure of). What role does the seed play?
458.instructor_answer: so the way PRNGs work is that they have an internal number, and when you call rand() they output that number (maybe with some processing like modulus, maybe just as raw bits), then do some math on it to get the next number.  The seed is what to initialize that internal value with. So a PRNG like rand() will always produce the same sequence of numbers if you give it the same seed.  It's not actually random, but it is pseudorandom, which means that it's hard to predict what sequence of numbers it will produce for a given seed without just running it.  Note that the default rand() isn't good enough at being random for cryptography, but you don't need to think about that right now. Salma: PRNG is pseudo-random number generator. You may read more here as well: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter02-variables/random-number

456.subject: overlapping scope between two variables with the same name.
456.content: From Snefru 6.4 https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter06-pointers/scope I was tracing this example where there is an overlapping scope between two variables with the same name. It turns out in the lines where their scopes overlap, both i's take on the same value (at first a garbage value, then 2). Why doesn't the first i remain with value 1 throughout the entire main body (i.e. it's scope)?
456.instructor_answer: The `i` that the debugger is showing you is the value of `I` in the current scope and `i#2` shows that this current instance of `i` is `i#2`. In other words, since the new `i` is shadowing the outer `i`, it is not shown by the debugger.

455.subject: Past midterm question 2020
455.content: I've been stuck on this question for a long time... Can someone please explain to me what is going on in this question? 20250218_092550.jpg
455.instructor_answer: The question is asking you to calculate e using a series, stopping when the terms get small. You may remember the Taylor series from calculus, this series is similar, in that each term is increasingly smaller so the sum converges to a value (e) even though there are an infinite number of terms.  We're asking you to calculate the sum of this series, stopping once the terms are small enough. For your solution, I'd suggest writing down the values of everything for the first few iterations of your loop, and the first few iterations of the loop in the solution.  You will quickly see that they are different. Recall that $$n! = 1\times2\times3\times4\times...\times n$$

416.subject: code followup LAB5 test cases don't work
416.content: #include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #define ARRAY_SIZE 21 //should NOT have a semicolon otherwise replaces ARRAY_SIZE with 21; , not 21 //prints " " or "*" depending on if the cell is dead (array[i] == 0) or alive (array[i] == 1) void printArray(int array[]){ for(int i=0; i<ARRAY_SIZE; i++){ if(array[i] == 0){ printf(" "); } else { printf("*"); //print the star only if the array at index i == 1 } } printf("\n"); //newline for the next iteraion } //initializes the values of each index void initializeArray(int aliveIndex, int array[]){ for(int i=0; i<ARRAY_SIZE; i++){ if(i != aliveIndex){ array[i] = 0; } else { array[i] = 1; } } printArray(array); //prints the array that was just initialized } //determines whether the centre cell will be dead (0) or alive (1), and returns that value int getRuleOutcome(int rule, int left, int center, int right){ int binaryRule[8] = {0}; //creates an array with 8 indices to store the value in each index (2^7 to 2^0) for(int i = 0; i < 8; i++){ binaryRule[i] = rule % 2; //sets each index to 0 or 1 rule /= 2; //integer division by 2 to get to the next base 2 to mod } int decimalLCR = left * 4 + center * 2 + right; //3 adjacent cells, represented by a 3 digit binary number (0 = alive, 1 = dead), are converted into decimal to correspond to a bit (0-7) return binaryRule[decimalLCR]; //return the value of the binary rule at the index determined by the arrangement of LCR (b_decimalLCR) } //iterates through currentArray, assigning the new value of the centre value, currentArray[i], to the next iteration, at the same index i in nextArray void calculateNextState(int currentArray[], int nextArray[], int rule){ int left, center, right; for(int i=0; i<ARRAY_SIZE; i++){ if(i==0){ //if i==0, the left of i must be the last index for a cyclic boundary left = currentArray[20]; center = currentArray[0]; right = currentArray[1]; } else if(i==ARRAY_SIZE-1) { //if i==the last index (ARRAY_SIZE - 1 or 20), the right must be index 0 for a cyclic boundary left = currentArray[19]; center = currentArray[20]; right = currentArray[0]; } else { left = currentArray[i-1]; center = currentArray[i]; right = currentArray[i+1]; } center = getRuleOutcome(rule, left, center, right); //see what the next state of the centre cell will be nextArray[i] = center; } } //simulates the generations for the specificed # iterations. This function is passed in the currentArray in array[], and defines the nextArray to then be printed. void simulateGenerations(int iterations, int array[], int rule){ int nextArray[ARRAY_SIZE] = {0}; //initialize the nextArray for(int i=0; i<iterations; i++){ calculateNextState(array, nextArray, rule); //calculate the next state of each cell printArray(nextArray); //print the new array for(int j=0; j<ARRAY_SIZE; j++){ //set the (now old) nextArray to array array[j] = nextArray[j]; } } } int main(void){ int aliveCell; //indicates the starting alive cell (integer from 0-20) int rule; //indicates the rule (integer from 0-255) int iterations; //indicates number of iterations (integer) printf("Enter input: "); scanf("%d %d %d", &aliveCell, &rule, &iterations); //take the 3 inputs int cells[ARRAY_SIZE] = {0}; //define the array initializeArray(aliveCell, cells); //initializes cells simulateGenerations(iterations, cells, rule); //simulates the Cellular Automaton for the specified # of iterations return EXIT_SUCCESS;
416.instructor_answer:
Simple mistake!

You are printing on more generation.

Since you are printing the array in initializeArray, then you go and print `iterations` number of generations, there is an additional generation.

I suggest not printing anything in initializeArray, and printing before calling calculateNextState in the loop. That would fix it.

384.content: Should we always set variables =0? Sometimes I do it and sometimes I don’t and it worked until lab 4 part 2 where it would not work unless I initialized all variables = 0 first.
384.instructor_answer: If a variable is not explicitly initialized, it contains whatever data was previously in that memory location. Generally, you should initialize your variables, unless you have good reason not to.

383.subject: return 0 in main()
383.content: We always use int main() and return 0 in its body. But we never really use the return 0 for anything so why not just make the prototype "void int main()" and return nothing?
383.instructor_answer:
The C standard specifies that main() must return an int.
This return value is significant, especially for programs that are run in environments where the operating system or other programs might need to check the program's exit status.
383.endorsed_answer:
The C standard specifies that main() must return an int.
This return value is significant, especially for programs that are run in environments where the operating system or other programs might need to check the program's exit status.

382.subject: formatting: x++ vs. x ++
382.content: In general for format on save something like "x<=0" would be come " x <= 0", including spaces before and after the operator. This seems to be true for +, -, =, etc. However when we do "x++" it does not reformat to "x ++". Why not? Shouldn't good formatting be consistent?
382.instructor_answer: For unary operators, adding a space between the operator and the operand generally makes the code harder to read. Many well-known coding style conventions explicitly prefer no spaces around increment/decrement operators.

317.subject: lab3 part2
317.content: Hi, I noticed that I would get the correct output when a1++ was put before the calculation of a t, y, but when it goes at the end of the while loop, I would get a number that is one degree greater than the correct answer. Could you please explain this to me? Thanks so much!
317.instructor_answer: Your y at the end of each iteration determines when the loop exits. When a1++ is placed before computing a and t , each iteration i (starting from 0) calculates a , t and y using a1 = i + 1 (assuming a1 is initialized as 0). If a1++ is placed after computing a and t , your a , t and y are actually computed using a1 = i , even though a1 becomes i + 1 at the end of the iteration, leading to one extra loop iteration.

290.subject: question about tutorial 3.3
290.content: Hi, My solution to question 3 works only some of the time and I was wondering if there were any fixes that I could implement without changing my general approach to the question. For the example below, I entered 5.643 and I'm expecting an output of 56 64 43, but it returns 56 64 42 because of some floating point issue with subtracting, which makes the number 5.6429999 Occasionally it does have the right output because the error will make it 5.64300001 or something similar. Thanks :)
290.instructor_answer:
Precision errors in `double` exists with certain numbers. Your solution works well for many other inputs. 

We haven't discussed this in class, and you are not expected to know it. However, if you add this line:

```
        number = (rint(number * pow(10, digits-i+1))/ pow(10, digits-i+1)) *10;

```

instead of number = number * 10; 

It will fix the problem by rounding the number first before multiplying it by 10 avoiding the precision errors. 

I highly encourage you to use the debugger after adding the line to see what happens that solves the problem. If you don't know how to use the debugger, please watch plenary lecture 3 on Quercus (at least the first 10 minutes).

286.subject: Textbook 5.1 Question
286.content: Hi, im reading the 5.1 Section for the textbook, and got kind of confused here, so for the following code, they have different order, for example: for the first picture function printStars comes before the function printPattern(from line 16 to line 26, but the second picture, the order is reserved, does the order of the function matter?
286.instructor_answer:
The order of implementing functions after the main function does not matter as long as they're implemented! In this case, since the function prototypes are at the top of the program before the main function, there is no need to worry about the order of implementations. 

The problem might happen when you don't have prototypes, instead you have only implementations before the main function. This is discussed here: https://learningc.org/chapters/chapter05-functions/functions#another-way-to-write-code-with-functions-but-not-favorable

256.subject: Lecture 9 question
256.content: Regarding the while loop example that we went over in class today, I missed the explanation as to why the code works even if the user inputs multiple number with spaces without pressing enter after each one. There is only one scan input function with one variable, how does the computer process this code?
256.instructor_answer:
If the user enters multiple numbers with spaces, the `scanf` outside the loop will only read the first number in the sequence of numbers. Where will the other numbers go? They'll remain there waiting for another `scanf` to read them.

This is why when the first number was > 0, the inner `scanf` read the next number in the sequence of numbers. 

For example, the user enters `10 5 3 2 -1`, 10 will be read by the `scanf` outside the loop, and then we will enter the loop and the `scanf` there will continue where we left off the last `scanf`, so it will read the 5.

Apologies for the late reply! I had a deadline these past few days :(

243.instructor_answer:
In the lab handout, there are general guidelines on what the TA looks at when grading your coding style. 

In plenary lecture 2, we discuss that. I highly encourage you to watch it. 

In short, you can use camelCase or snake_case for variable names. They should be descriptive, not `r`, `x`, `y`. Instead, they should be `radius`, `escapeVelocity`, `price`.

For the formatting, if you have set up the formatter in lab 0, you should be able to press on Crtl+S (on Windows) or Cmd+S (on Mac) to fix spacing. 

You should also have comments for each block of code.

230.subject: memorize ASCII values?
230.content: Would such a question come up on the midterm or final, where we need to know the ASCII values for certain characters? I do not have it memorized. (from textbook)
230.instructor_answer: You don’t have to memorize the ascii code of any character.
230.endorsed_answer: Numbers and letters in ASCII are sequential (i.e. '0' < '1' < '2'... or 'A' < 'B' < 'C'... or 'a' < 'b' <'c'). Upper cases come before lower cases but the two aren't sequential with respect to each other—there are some characters in between upper and lower case letters. As Professor Emara has said you don't have to memorize the code but it could help to know in certain instances when writing code (i.e. you want to turn the character 'a' to 'b', you know that 'a' + 1 = 'b').

226.subject: dividing by 0
226.content: Dividing by 0 can lead to different results, whether it be garbage values or inf, etc. It was mentioned in class that we will use if statements to prevent the division by zero. Why doesn't C just disable the division by zero and categorize it as it an error so that we don't have to deal with this? Perhaps is there something useful about the inf or garbage value?
226.instructor_answer:
It's a philosophy in C to allow multiple low-level operations that don't make sense. This gives the programmer utmost responsibility for their code to define what to do in some cases, instead of automatically detecting it. 

If C automatically detects it, C might take ~~less~~ more time to run. The speed of running C/C++ are one of their main advantages in my opinion. 

As we start discussing memory management, you will realize how much is C giving the programmer a lot of freedom. 

Other languages like Rust, have different philosophies preventing the programmer from doing many things. I have to say it's very annoying for a beginner. 

Hope this helps!

224.subject: Mass unit
224.content: "Your program must handle the unit conversions as well as printing the planet's mass in terms of 10211021 kg." For this, say the circumference is 3800, and the other numbers are accordingly adjusted. Should the mass still be the first 4 digits? Even if that means 10^ negative exponent?
224.instructor_answer:
You need to convert all input km to metres before you do any calculations.

After that, you calculate radius (in metres), mass (in kg) and velocity (in m/s). 

After the calculation, you have to do you conversions into km.

For the mass, since it is always written in x 10^21 format, you need to divide the mass by 10^21 before you print it. 

Hope this helps!

213.subject: truncate/floor/round down
213.content: Is truncated and floored and rounding down all the same meaning where we just ignore everything after the decimal point?
213.endorsed_answer: Not exactly, Since flooring removes the decimal but also considers the negatives, like -2.2 -> -3 rounding down moves to the lower integer, they are not identical. I guess truncate is just ignoring, yeah Edit: I believe that flooring in C is equivalent to rounding down, so something like -2.2 will be floored to -3 as seen above. ( https://www.techonthenet.com/c_language/standard_library_functions/math_h/floor.php) The wording regarding truncating is a bit confusing, truncating will simply "cut off" the decimal, and just give you whatever is in the ones place and higher. You can always try different examples and see what happens,

212.subject: exploring C
212.content: When I did a Python course, we could write code in an IDE. But I thin out outside the IDE we could also directly on Python type code such as "1+1", then hit enter and see the result "2". Is there a way I can set this up? It would make it easier to explore C. Also I may me describing unclearly or somewhat incorrectly as I am not too sure what it is exactly.
212.instructor_answer: Notice a very important difference between Python and C. Python is not a compile-time language. It's an interpreted language. You write some code in python and you can run it interactively. This is not the case for C. C is a compile-time language. You have to compile your program and run it. In theory, there is no chance that standalone C can allow you to do it. The only thing you can do is to write code, compile it and run it.
212.endorsed_answer: Notice a very important difference between Python and C. Python is not a compile-time language. It's an interpreted language. You write some code in python and you can run it interactively. This is not the case for C. C is a compile-time language. You have to compile your program and run it. In theory, there is no chance that standalone C can allow you to do it. The only thing you can do is to write code, compile it and run it.

132.subject: Function Prototype vs Function Declaration
132.content: In today's lecture (with Prof Eyolfson), we learned that function prototype is similar to function declaration. Can someone please explain the difference between these two? I know Java and I am trying to learn C by creating similarities between the concepts in these two languages. I believe that function prototype in C is the same as calling a method in Java. Is function declaration in C be the same as method definition in Java? Or am I misunderstanding these concepts?
132.instructor_answer: Calling a method isn't the same as a function prototype. A function prototype is closer to creating a method. In both C and Java you can call functions (a method is basically a function). In Java, when you _define_ (create) a method, you're also declaring it. From what I remember with Java, you can't just declare a method. If you want to be specific, you're declaring and defining a method at the same time. (A method is basically a function, but has a hidden argument for the object). Also, you can overload methods in Java, so methods with different arguments can have the same name. In C, you cannot overload functions. A "declaration" in C, would just be declaring that there is a function with a name. You could do `int foo();`, that declares a function called foo, but doesn't tell you anything about the arguments. A prototype includes all arguments as well, so `int foo(int, int);` would be a prototype. All declarations are prototypes, but not all prototypes are declarations. Let me know if that makes sense. Sorry if it's a bit dense :)

113.subject: Lab 1 Part 1 Print Statement Formatting
113.content: For lab 1 part 1, I know that it is possible to use only one very long print statement to print the entire paragraph. However, this long line is not very readable. Is it okay to create more print statements to reduce efficiency but increase readability?
113.instructor_answer: Yes, you won't notice a difference in the runtime, and printf has tricks to go faster. There's a common saying: premature optimization is the root of all evil. In other words, don't try to optimize things that don't need to be. You'll likely make it less readable. Focus on making it correct and readable first.

102.subject: Bool size
102.content: If a bool only stores a 1 or 0, why does it need a byte size? Why cant a bool just be a bit size?
102.instructor_answer: This is due to the fact that most OS and CPU can only handle byte as its finest granuality. Jon: You can only address memory one byte at a time (that's the smallest unit), and C says variables must be able to live in memory, so that's as small as it can be.

With the test cases provided, I understand that this format specifier will round the double. I would like some clarification if I used the correct format specifier with the example below: The price for the order should be (unrounded): $$1.5 * 3 * 1.13 = 5.0850$$. Since the digit following the " 5 " in the thousandths place is a 0 (5.08 5 0 ), the number should round down. Does the format specifier of "%.2lf" account for this rule or am I using the wrong method to round the double?

84.subject: Lab 1 FAQ
84.content: Q1- Can inputs be double? A1- For parts 2 and 3, inputs are always integers, except for prices. Q2- Can I use the math library to round numbers? A2- For parts 2 and 3, please use the format specifier for double to round to the nearest 2 decimal places. Don't use the math library. Q3- My compilation failed at the submission compeng.gg page. What do I do? A3- You should submit all three parts part1.c, part2.c and part3.c, for the compilation to happen correctly. You may alternatively have files for parts you didn't yet get started to do and write empty main functions there. Q4- How do we round to the nearest inch in part 3? A4- The program should print the length in feet and inches without any fractional part in inches. Hint: Use type cast of `int` to display the inches.

79.subject: Byte and Address
79.content: I am a little confused by this lecture slide, why is 0 represented as different addresses if it is the same value.
79.instructor_answer: It's not 0 being represented at different addresses. It's the value 0 is stored at several different addresses. Let me know if that makes sense!
79.endorsed_answer: The slide is showing that all four of those addresses contain the value 0, as opposed to the value zero being represented by four addresses. Think of it like having two variables with the same value. Despite this, you still want to store them in separate addresses so that you can access them individually. Hope this helps!

19.subject: Lab 0 code not running
19.content: Hi, I am trying to run this code but it keeps giving me this message in the bottom right corner. How can I fix this?
19.instructor_answer:
The error in the terminal says that there are multiple definitions of the main function. This is because you have two .c files in the same folder. 

Here is what to do to fix it. Create another folder (The icon next to New File), then drag and drop of the .c files (for example hello-world.c) into that new folder, and re-compile and run.

2.subject: Tips & Tricks for a successful class

1.subject: Welcome to Piazza!
1.content:
Piazza is a Q&A platform designed to get you great answers from classmates and instructors fast. We've put together this list of tips you might find handy as you get started: Ask questions! The best way to get answers is to ask questions! Ask questions on Piazza rather than emailing your teaching staff so everyone can benefit from the response (and so you can get answers from classmates who are up as late as you are). Edit questions and answers wiki-style. Think of Piazza as a Q&A wiki for your class. Every question has just a single students' answer that students can edit collectively (and a single instructors’ answer for instructors). Add a followup to comment or ask further questions. To comment on or ask further questions about a post, start a followup discussion . Mark it resolved when the issue has been addressed, and add any relevant information back into the Q&A above. Go anonymous. Shy? No problem. You can always opt to post or edit anonymously. Tag your posts. It's far more convenient to find all posts about your Homework 3 or Midterm 1 when the posts are tagged. Type a “#” before a key word to tag. Click a blue tag in a post or the question feed to filter for all posts that share that tag. Format code and equations. Adding a code snippet? Click the pre or tt button in the question editor to add pre-formatted or inline teletype text. 
Mathematical equation? Click the Fx button to access the LaTeX editor to build a nicely formatted equation. View and download class details and resources. Click the Course Page button in your top bar to access the class syllabus, staff contact information, office hours details, and course resources—all in one place!


Contact the Piazza Team anytime with questions or comments at team@piazza.com . We love feedback!
